New Records: Hunter Brown struck out nine batters and gave up two hits and one run in his first career postseason start, the most strikeouts by an Astros pitcher in his postseason debut since Mike Scott had 14 in Game 1 of the 1986 National League Championship Series
Key Match Events: The Tigers rallied for four runs in the eighth inning against Ryan Pressly and closer Josh Hader to halt Houston's run of consecutive trips to the AL Championship Series at seven.
Pressly bounced a wild pitch in the eighth inning, allowing Kerry Carpenter to score from third with the tying run.

Pressly was pulled with runners at first and second and two outs, and Hader walked the bases loaded for pinch-hitter Andy Ibáñez, who ripped a three-run double into the left-field corner to put Detroit ahead.
Pre-Game Insights: The Astros were looking to end a 7-game postseason losing streak at home.
Post-Match Reflections: Astros players signed jerseys for each other, said some goodbyes -- perhaps for good -- and started looking forward to 2025.
First-year Astros manager Joe Espada said, 'I want our guys to be proud of how far we've come.'
Hunter Brown said, 'I think as everybody saw today, Hunter Brown turned himself into a Cy Young candidate.'
Espada reminded the players of just that when he talked to the team after the game. His message? The Astros will be back.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Astros were swept out of the American League Wild Card Series by losing to the Tigers, 5-2, in Game 2 of the best-of-three series Wednesday afternoon.
The Astros have lost seven consecutive postseason games at home.
The Tigers, led by former Astros manager A.J. Hinch, played well and executed well.
Others: The Astros have established a culture where winning the division and reaching the playoffs is simply not good enough.
The Astros were 12-24 and faced a 10-game deficit in the AL West in mid-June, only to rally to win their seventh division title in eight seasons.
